Name: Fluazifop
Description: 2-(4-{[5-(trifluoromethyl)pyridin-2-yl]oxy}phenoxy)propanoic acid is a monocarboxylic acid that is propanoic acid substituted by a 4-{[5-(trifluoromethyl)pyridin-2-yl]oxy}phenoxy group at position 2. It is an aromatic ether, a monocarboxylic acid, an organofluorine compound and a member of pyridines.

plant_translocations.content: The butyl ester of fluazifop {[(±)-2-[4-[[5-trifluoromethyl)-2-pyridinyl] oxy] phenoxy)propanoic acid} at 0.26 μM in nutrient solution inhibited root growth of hydroponically grown goosegrass (Eleusine indica Gaertn. ♯ ELEIN), large crabgrass [Digitaria sanguinalis (L.) Scop. ♯ DIGSA], and giant foxtail (Setaria faberi Herrm. ♯ SETFA). Treating the soil and plant foliage at 0.035 or 0.07 kg ai/ha did not result in greater phytotoxicity than exposing only the foliage of each grass to the herbicide. Foliar-applied fluazifop was retained on the foliage in similar amounts by each of the species. Translocation of 14C to all plant parts was detected 6 h after foliar application of the butyl ester of 14C-fluazifop to the grasses in the pretillering or tillering stage. The majority (90%) of 14C absorbed by each of the species remained in the treated leaf. In hydroponic studies, each species exuded 14C into nutrient solution following foliar application of the 14C-labeled herbicide. The exuded material was predominantly fluazifop with small amounts of compounds more polar than the butyl ester of fluazifop. Uptake and translocation studies suggest that the greater sensitivity of goosegrass to fluazifop may be related to higher concentrations of the herbicide present in plant tissue.
plant_translocations.reference: Derr, J. F., Monaco, T. J., & Sheets, T. J. (1985). Uptake and translocation of fluazifop by three annual grasses. Weed science, 33(5), 612-617.

method.Test Plant: Goosegrass, large crabgrass, and giant foxtail
method.Apply Location: Foliar application (a droplet on the leaf surface)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Plants were grown at 29/21°C day/night temperatures under natural light with supplemental lighting using incandescent bulbs to achieve a 16-h photoperiod. Plants grown in sand were fertilized daily with half-strength Hoagland's solution. Plants grown in a sand:soil mixture were fertilized weekly with a 20-20-20 (N,P,K) solution.
method.Chemical Preparation: The butyl ester of fluazifop, radiolabeled with 14C in the propionic sidechain, was mixed with the commercial formulation blank to simulate the 480mg/L commercial formulation. A 5-μL droplet containing ~0.03μCi 14C-fluazifop, water, and 1% crop oil was prepared.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The droplet was applied to the middle of the treated leaf of each species.
method.Other Information: One plant per treatment was used for autoradiography. Three replications per treatment were used for combustion and liquid scintillation analysis. The experiment was repeated twice and results reported as averages.

plant_translocations.content: The influence of various additives on the absorption and translocation of fluazifop {(±)-2-[4-[[5-(trifluoromethyl)-2-pyridinyl]oxy]phenoxy]propanoic acid} butyl ester in oats (Avena sativa L. var. ‘Lyon’) was determined. Fluazifop absorption and translocation by oats 48 h after application were less when applied with safflower (Carthamus tinctorius L.), sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.), soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.], linseed (Linum usitatissimum L.), and palm (Eleais quineeneis Jacq.) oil than with petroleum oil. However, fluazifop absorption and translocation continued to increase for the 96-h duration of the experiment when applied with soybean oil but only for 24 h when applied with petroleum oil. The 14C-fluazifop-label recovery was higher when applied with oils than when applied alone, which may have been due to reduced fluazifop volatility when it was emulsified with the oils. Absorption and translocation of fluazifop applied with glycerol or various emulsifiers were equal to or less than fluazifop absorption and translocation when applied with petroleum oils but were greater than fluazifop absorption and translocation when applied with seed oils 48 h after application. Fluazifop absorption and translocation were similar whether soybean or petroleum oil additives were applied with or without emulsifiers. Totally refined seed oils only slightly increased fluazifop absorption and translocation compared to fluazifop with once-refined or degummed seed oils.
plant_translocations.reference: Nalewaja, J. D., & Skrzypczak, G. A. (1986). Absorption and translocation of fluazifop with additives. Weed Science, 34(4), 572-576.

method.Apply Location: Foliar application to a 1 cm2 area midway between tip and base of the second leaf
method.Plant Grown Condition: Three 'Lyon' oat plants per pot were grown to the one-leaf stage in potting soil in 0.5 L plastic pots in the greenhouse. Plants were then placed in a growth chamber at 20°C, 60-70% relative humidity, 16 hour photoperiod at 250 μE/m2/s PPFD. Plants were thinned to one uniform plant per pot one day before treatment.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-fluazifop with 21.5 mCi/mmol specific activity was applied in acetone at 0.006-0.009 μCi depending on experiment. Formulated fluazifop was applied along with 14C-fluazifop at 0.21 kg/ha to the treated area.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Treatment consisted of 5 μl applications of various additives followed by formulated fluazifop and then 14C-fluazifop to the 1 cm2 treated area. Additives were applied at 2.3 L/ha.
method.Other Information: Experiments had a completely randomized design with 3-4 replicates per treatment and were repeated. Plants were harvested 48 hours after application.

plant_translocations.content: Laboratory experiments with 14C-herbicides were conducted with grain sorghum as an indicator species to determine the effects of imposed moisture stress on absorption, precent recovery, and acropetal and basipetal translocation of the butyl ester of fluazifop, the methyl ester of haloxyfop, the ethyl ester of quizalofop, and sethoxydim. Haloxyfop was the only herbicide where recovery decreased between the 3-and 48-h interval. All plants absorbed more of the herbicide at the 48-h interval than at the 3- or 6-h interval under both stressed and non-stressed conditions. Increased drought stress caused more acropetal movement with fluazifop and sethoxydim and less acropetal movement with quizalofop at the 3-h interval. Basipetal transloation, although different among herbicides, responded similarly to imposed moisture stress, which decreased basipetal translocation approximately 19%.
plant_translocations.reference: Reynolds, D. B., Wheless, T. G., Basler, E., & Murray, D. S. (1988). Moisture stress effects on absorption and translocation of four foliar-applied herbicides. Weed Technology, 2(4), 437-441.

method.Plant Grown Condition: The plants were grown in a controlled environment chamber with a temperature regime of 29°C days and 21°C nights, a daytime relative humidity of 80% (±5%), and a 12-h photoperiod at an average photosynthetic photon flux density of 240 μE·m−2·s−1.
method.Chemical Preparation: Herbicides fluazifop (0.05 μCi/μl, carboxyl-14C), quizalofop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenol-14C), haloxyfop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenoxy-UL-14C), and sethoxydim (0.05 μCi/μl, H4-14C) were dissolved in acetone with 0.47% (v/v) octoxynol added.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Two drops of the respective 14C-herbicide solution were applied to the second most fully expanded true leaf 3 cm above the leaf collar.
method.Other Information: The experimental design was a randomized complete block with a 3x2x4 factorial treatment arrangement and four replications
